results.title: The Rainbow and the forest
results.brief_description: Of all the butterflies in the British Isles, the “Purple Emperor” is in a class of its own. Apart from the fact that it is so magnificent, most people have never been priviledged to see it in the wild, and collectors regard it as the greatest prize of all. The entire development of this butterfly - the forests it lives in, and its unusual habits were captured on film by a small team who virtually lived with these insects for a year.

results.title: The Rain forest
results.creator_credit: Education Media Australia, David Corke and Bruce Amos
results.brief_description: Filmed in the McPherson Ranges in southern Queensland, capturing the watery atmosphere, eerie sounds, fragile plants and delicate patterns of light which penetrate the dense foliage. The main highlight is a vast camp of flying foxes hanging from the palms, fanning themselves with extended wing membrane.

results.title: The Railwaymen
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Film & Television, John Richardson and Kevin Anderson
results.brief_description: The days of steam which heralded the start of Australia’s inland rail system evoke romantic memories of a bygone era, as well as a recognition of the interdependence between rail and industry success. But what of the people who helped build Australia’s outback railways- the engineers and surveyors whose vision and skill overcame the impossible barriers of desert and mountain range, and the workers who suffered great hardship in building and maintaining them? This documentary uses the words and voices of the men and women that contributed to this history, and those that are continuing to add to it today. Features footage on the following railways: Zig Zag Railway, Blue Mountains; The ABT Railway, Tasmania; The Ghan, Central Australia; Trans-Australia Railway, Nullabor Plain; R-707, Melbourne to Gippsland; and Kuranda Scenic Railway, Queensland.

results.title: The Railway station = La Stazione
results.brief_description: Flavia, a rich and beautiful young society woman flees from an outlandish party, when she discovers her presence there served only to secure a business deal for her violent over-bearing lover Danilo. Attempting to leave her predicament on the first available train, Flavia seeks refuge in a small railway station where she meets Domenico, a shy and modest station-master who offers her both moral support and shelter from the impending storm. While spending the night together awaiting the arrival of the morning train, the pair become hopelessly drawn to each other despite their apparent class differences. In Italian language with English subtitles.

results.title: The Railway children. Swallows and amazons [DVD]
results.creator_credit: EMI/Parlophone, Robert Lynn, Richard Pilbrow, Lionel Jeffries and Claude Whatham
results.brief_description: Set at the turn of the century, this is a story based on E. Nesbit’s novel, “The Railway Children”. It is much more than a happy-ever-after dream, evoking a nostalgia for a perfect world that exists only in our imaginations. Swallows and amazons: Arthur Ransome’s immortal story is the bright, breezy and colourful tale of six children on holiday in the Lake District during the glorious summer of 1929. As they happily mess around in boats, their friendly rivalry is filled with imaginary dangers and piracy. Based on one of the best loved books of all time, their exciting exploits are a handbook to adventure for children of all ages.

results.title: The Railrodder
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Julian Biggs and Gerald Potterton
results.brief_description: A humorous trip across Canada from the Atlantic to the Pacific with Buster Keaton riding on a rail “trike” which contains everything he needs in the way of food, clothing, tools, bedding, shaving gear, and even a rifle. This is Buster Keaton’s last film, made by the National Film Board before he died. It is a travelogue with a difference.

results.title: The Rail way
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Department of Transport, Don Murray and Greg Reading
results.brief_description: A look at railways in Australia from Alice Springs to Kalgoorlie and Normanton. Shows trains serving the mining fields in central Queensland and the suburban trains of the big cities. Discusses problems brought about by different gauges throughout the country, and looks at the economic future of railways. Commentator Patsy Adam-Smith.

results.title: The Rage in Placid Lake
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Rapacious Pictures, Showtime, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Marian MacGowan and Tony McNamara
results.brief_description: A boy called “Placid Lake” is becoming a man. Tormented all through school for being different and for being the product of his new age parents, Placid (Ben Lee) has a reason for being angry. He decides to exact a type of revenge on his parents by having a career in insurance. Helped through life by his academically brilliant and crayon-chewing friend Gemma (Rose Byrne), will Placid survive the bland 9-to-5 of corporate life? Written and directed by Tony McNamara, adapted from his play “The Cafe Latte Kid”. Features music by Ben Lee and Cezary Skubiszewski. Cast includes Garry McDonald, Miranda Richardson.
